system_prompt_used:
You are a helpful and accurate Latin language assistant. You are fluent in Latin, including authentic classical Latin style and tone, and you have an expert understanding of Latin grammatical structures. You use your knowledge to help Latin instructors simplify classical Latin passages so they are understandable for students who have finished two years of college Latin.

Your goal is to generate a grammatically simpler version of a Latin passage provided by the instructor. Below are four URLs you can refer to for vocabulary and grammar. 

The Latinitium dictionary includes word definitions and parts of speech. https://latinitium.com/latin-dictionaries/
The Dickinson College Commentaries gives guidance on many different grammatical structures. https://dcc.dickinson.edu/grammar/latin/index 
The Hedera Latin Logeion is a vocabulary list with meanings. https://github.com/Hedera-Lang-Learn/hedera/blob/dev/data/grc/logeion-latin.txt 
Wiktionary Deponent Verbs lists Latin deponent verbs. https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Latin_deponent_verbs

Although you should interact with the instructor in English, you should not translate the provided Latin passage into English.

Here is the process you should follow:

1. Analyze the provided Latin text to identify key ideas and important details. Make sure to identify important context so you can preserve it in the simplified passage. Pay particular attention to dialog, noting who is speaking, who they are speaking to, and the subjects and objects of each statement.
2. Rephrase the original Latin in the passage into simpler Latin, using grammar and high-frequency vocabulary appropriate for second-year Latin students. In particular, follow these rules when simplifying the passage:
    - Do not omit any key ideas or important details.
    - Retain all of the important context from the original passage.
    - Do not add any new information to the passage. 
    - Do not include more than two dependent/subordinate clauses per sentence.
    - If the original passage includes any of the following forbidden grammatical structures, replace them with simpler structures that are not forbidden. Refer to the URLs given above to help you identify the part of speech or meaning of a word if needed:
        - subjunctive mood verbs
        - gerunds
        - gerundives
        - supines
        - impersonal use of the passive voice
        - double dative construction
    - When you simplify the passage, do not add any of the forbidden grammatical structures listed above. 
3. Before providing your response, compare the original passage to the simplified version. Verify that all the key ideas and context have been retained. Pay special attention to dialog, making sure that the speaker, listener, subjects, and objects of all dialog are the same as in the original passage. If they are not, revise the simplified passage so it preserves the key ideas and context from the original passage.
4. Before providing your response, check the simplified passage and confirm that it does not contain any of the forbidden grammatical structures listed above. If the passage still contains any of the forbidden grammatical structures, rephrase those parts of the passage so they do not use any of the forbidden structures.
5. Present your output in the following form:
    - Display, "Here is the simplified passage:"
    - Print the simplified passage. Do not include any commentary or translation.


Worked Example:

Here is an example of an appropriate simplification. The original passage was: "post eius mortem nihilo minus Helvetii id quod constituerant facere conantur, ut e finibus suis exeant. Ubi iam se ad eam rem paratos esse arbitrati sunt, oppida sua omnia, numero ad duodecim, vicos ad quadringentos, reliqua privata aedificia incendunt;  frumentum omne, praeter quod secum portaturi erant, comburunt, ut domum reditionis spe sublata paratiores ad omnia pericula subeunda essent; trium mensum molita cibaria sibi quemque domo efferre iubent. Persuadent Rauracis et Tulingis et Latobrigis finitimis, uti eodem usi consilio oppidis suis vicisque exustis una cum iis proficiscantur".

Here is a simplified version of this passage that is appropriate for second-year Latin students: "post eius mortem nihilominus Helvetii id consilium, quod constituerant, facere conantur. id est, e finibus suis exire conantur. ubi iam se paratos esse arbitrati sunt, oppida sua omnia (circa duodecim), vicos (circa quadringentos), reliqua privata aedificia incendunt.  frumentum omne, praeter id quod secum portaturi erant, incendunt.  spe domum reditionis sublata, putant se futuros esse paratiores subire omnia pericula. iubent quemque sibi cibaria trium mensum domo effere iubent. persuadent finitimis gentibus, Rauracis et Tulingis et Latobrigis, qui eodem consilio uti constituunt. oppidis suis vicisque incensis, una cum Helvetiis proficiscentur".
user_prompt_used:
sed fatis incerta feror, si Iuppiter unam
esse velit Tyriis urbem Troiaque profectis,
miscerive probet populos aut foedera iungi.
tu coniunx, tibi fas animum temptare precando.
perge, sequar.” tum sic excepit regia Iuno:
“mecum erit iste labor. nunc qua ratione quod instat
confieri possit, paucis (adverte) docebo.
venatum Aeneas unaque miserrima Dido
in nemus ire parant, ubi primos crastinus ortus
extulerit Titan radiisque retexerit orbem.

message.content:
Here is the simplified passage:

sed fatis incerta feror, si Iuppiter unam  
esse vult Tyriis urbem Troiaque profectis,  
miscere probat populos aut foedera iungi.  
tu coniunx, tibi fas animum temptare precando.  
perge, sequam.” tum sic excepit regia Iuno:  
“mecum erit iste labor. nunc qua ratione quod instat  
confieri potest, paucis (adverte) docebo.  
venatum Aeneas unaque miserrima Dido  
in nemus ire parant, ubi primos crastinus ortus  
extollet Titan radiisque retexet orbem.
message.reasoning_content:
Okay, let's tackle this. The user wants me to simplify a Latin passage for second-year students. First, I need to analyze the original text. Let's look at the lines from the Aeneid provided.

The passage involves dialogue between characters, probably Dido and Aeneas, with Juno intervening. Key points: uncertainty of fate, Jupiter's will regarding the Tyrians and Trojans joining, the plan to hunt, and Juno's involvement.

Now, checking for forbidden structures. The original has subjunctives like "feror" (if that's subjunctive?), "velit", "probet", "iungi" (passive infinitive?), "temptare", "sequar", "excepit", "possit", "adverte", "extulerit", "retexerit". Also, "miscerive" is a gerundive? Wait, "miscerive" is a contraction of "miscere + -ve", so it's an infinitive. Maybe not a gerundive. Let me confirm. "probet populos aut foedera iungi" – "iungi" is passive infinitive, which is allowed? The rules say to replace subjunctives, gerunds, gerundives, supines, impersonal passives, double datives.

So, the task is to replace subjunctives with indicatives or other constructions. Let's go line by line.

"sed fatis incerta feror" – "feror" is present passive, but "incerta" is feminine, so the subject is Dido. Maybe rephrase to "feror" as passive, but not sure if that's an issue. The user said to avoid impersonal passives, but this is personal. So maybe okay.

"si Iuppiter unam esse velit Tyriis urbem Troiaque profectis" – "velit" is subjunctive. Replace with "vult" indicative. "Tyriis" dative, "Troiaque profectis" dative. So "if Jupiter wants there to be one city for the Tyrians and those who set out from Troy."

"miscerive probet populos aut foedera iungi." – "probet" subjunctive, change to "probat". "iungi" passive infinitive, maybe replace with active if possible. "aut foedera iungi" – "or that treaties be joined" → "aut foedera iunguntur" (present passive) or find an active construction. Maybe "aut ut foedera iungant" but that's subjunctive again. Hmm. Alternatively, "aut foedera iungere" as infinitive, but the original uses "probet" with infinitive? Wait, "probet" is subjunctive in original, so "approves to mix the peoples or that treaties be joined." Changing "probet" to "probat" and "iungi" to "iungere" (active infinitive) might not make sense. Maybe rephrase the entire clause.

"tu coniunx, tibi fas animum temptare precando." – "temptare" is infinitive, which is okay. "fas" is impersonal, but the user didn't mention that as forbidden. Maybe keep.

"perge, sequar.” – "sequar" is future or present subjunctive? It's future indicative: "I will follow." Wait, "sequar" is 1st person singular future indicative of "sequor". So that's allowed. No subjunctive here.

"tum sic excepit regia Iuno" – "excepit" is perfect indicative, okay.

"mecum erit iste labor. nunc qua ratione quod instat confieri possit, paucis (adverte) docebo." – "possit" is subjunctive. Change to "potest". "adverte" is imperative, allowed.

"venatum Aeneas unaque miserrima Dido in nemus ire parant, ubi primos crastinus ortus extulerit Titan radiisque retexerit orbem." – "extulerit" and "retexerit" are future perfect indicatives. Wait, future perfect is allowed. So no problem. But maybe students haven't learned future perfect yet. The user didn't specify, but the rules say to avoid subjunctives, etc. Since future perfect is indicative, it's allowed. So maybe keep.

Now, reconstructing each line with substitutions:

Original: "sed fatis incerta feror, si Iuppiter unam esse velit Tyriis urbem Troiaque profectis, miscerive probet populos aut foedera iungi."

Simplified: Replace "velit" with "vult", "probet" with "probat", "iungi" with "iunguntur" (present passive). So: "sed fatis incerta feror, si Iuppiter unam esse vult Tyriis urbem Troiaque profectis, miscere probat populos aut foedera iunguntur."

But "miscerive" is "miscere + -ve", so "aut miscere probat populos". Maybe rephrase to "aut probat populos misceri aut foedera iungi" but that uses passive infinitives. Alternatively, "aut populos miscet aut foedera iungit" – but that changes meaning. Hmm. Maybe keep the structure but adjust the verbs.

Alternatively: "si Iuppiter vult unam urbem esse Tyriis et Troianis profectis, et probat populos misceri aut foedera iungi." But "probat" with infinitive is okay? Maybe. But the original uses "miscerive probet" – "approves to mix or to join". So maybe "probat miscere populos aut iungere foedera." But "miscere" is active infinitive, which would mean "approves to mix the peoples or to join treaties." That might work.

Next line: "tu coniunx, tibi fas animum temptare precando. perge, sequar.” – Keep as is, since "temptare" is infinitive, "perge" imperative, "sequar" future indicative.

Juno's response: "mecum erit iste labor. nunc qua ratione quod instat confieri possit, paucis (adverte) docebo." – Change "possit" to "potest". So: "nunc qua ratione quod instat confieri potest, paucis (adverte) docebo."

Last lines: "venatum Aeneas unaque miserrima Dido in nemus ire parant, ubi primos crastinus ortus extulerit Titan radiisque retexerit orbem." – Future perfects are okay, but maybe replace with future simple for simplicity. "extulerit" → "extollet", "retexerit" → "retexet". So: "ubi primos crastinus ortus extollet Titan radiisque retexet orbem."

Putting it all together, making sure the dialogue parts are preserved, speakers are correct, and no forbidden structures. Let me check each part again for subjunctives, gerunds, etc. Also, ensure sentences don't have more than two dependent clauses.

Final simplified passage should maintain all key ideas without adding or omitting anything. Let me verify each line again.
